Award.AbstractNarration:
How should spouses behave while discussing the problems that will inevitably arise over the course of their marriages? Numerous theoretical perspectives posit that maintaining satisfaction with an intimate relationship requires exchanging positive behaviors, such as forgiving, and avoiding negative ones, such as blaming, commanding, and rejecting. Accordingly, most educational programs train couples to exchange positive behaviors and avoid more negative ones. Nevertheless, studies of the efficacy of such programs indicate that although spouses do learn new skills they do not remain more satisfied over the long-term. One reason for this lack of success may be that programs are teaching the wrong skills. Indeed, although some studies indicate that spouses benefit from avoiding negative behaviors, other studies indicate that spouses benefit from engaging in negative behaviors. Whether spouses benefit from avoiding or engaging in negative behaviors while discussing their problems may depend on an overlooked factor - the nature of the problem being discussed. Prior research indicates that engaging in negative behaviors can motivate partners to change. Although such behaviors may be unnecessary during discussions of minor problems or problems out of the partner's control, they may be necessary to motivate partners to address serious problems that are under the partner's control. Accordingly, it may be most adaptive for spouses to be flexible in how they behave - avoiding or engaging in negative behaviors depending on whether they are discussing a problem that is controllable and severe.

The proposed study will examine the tendency for spouses to flexibly calibrate their negative behaviors to both the severity and controllability of the specific problem they are discussing. At baseline and one year later, 200 newlywed couples will complete four problem-solving interactions (two that target a relatively minor problem and two that target a relatively severe problem) that will be rated by independent judges for negative behavior, severity, and controllability. Also at baseline, and every three months for two years, participants will report their marital satisfaction, the severity of their marital problems, and their motivation to resolve those problems. Analyses will test the hypothesis that spouses who engage in fewer negative behaviors while discussing minor and relatively uncontrollable problems but more negative behaviors while discussing severe and controllable problems remain more satisfied over time, and that such associations occur because properly calibrated negative behavior motivates the partner to change and thus help resolve problems. Not only will this research promote the training of the numerous graduate and undergraduate students necessary to carry out the research, support for the predictions would suggest that existing education programs should not continue teaching spouses to avoid negative behaviors altogether but should instead teach them to properly calibrate such behaviors to severe and controllable problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current research assessed whether people who tend engage in more oppositional behaviors during discussions of their more severe problems but to avoid such behaviors during discussions of more minor problems have better marital outcomes over time. To test this possibility, we recruited a sample of 120 newlywed couples to our laboratory to discuss four problems. A team of four undergraduate and three graduate students coded every speaking turn from videos of these conversations for oppositional behavior. We also asked each partner to answer several questions about each discussion before it occurred, including questions about the severity of the problem and potential solutions to the problem. Finally, we asked both members of the couples to report their marital satisfaction at baseline and then again nine more times, once every four months. All but 5 of the 240 people provided at least two reports of marital satisfaction. Thus, our primary analyses are based on 98% of the original sample. 


To estimate spouses' tendencies to calibrate their oppositional behaviors to more severe problems, we used a random effects model to estimate the within-person association between each person’s ratings of severity of the problem and the proportion of their speaking turns that was coded as oppositional. In this analysis, each person receives a behavioral calibration score, which is essentially an estimate of the extent to which that person engages in more oppositional behaviors during discussions of more severe problems. When then used those scores to predict marital outcomes. Our most interesting findings regard the calibration measure itself. Partners were indeed more likely to calibrate their oppositional behaviors to the severity of the problem being discussed. That is, for both husbands and wives, the use of opposition was positively associated with perceived problem severity reported before the conversation. Nevertheless, individual differences in calibration did not predict changes in satisfaction. There may be too reasons for this. First, there was very little variability in calibration, suggesting that most couples calibrated the same way, leaving us little room for comparisons on outcomes. Second, there is some evidence that calibration was not necessarily as strategic as we thought it would be--it appeared to instead stem from frustration rather than strategically enacted during discussions of solvable problems.    

There is high value in this data set beyond the variables assessed to directly test the proposed hypotheses. We assessed numerous other variables, to be used as possible covariates and moderators, but also to test other ideas, and some of the variables collected to test the primary aim provide a wealth of additional information. For example, the recorded videos of the couples engaged in the problem-solving discussion provide opportunities to capture countless variables.  Further, the outcome variable targeted by our primary aim, change in marital satisfaction over the first three years of marriage, is itself a critical outcome that may be related to numerous baseline variables. We captured such change very reliably. Not only did we see substantial change in marital satisfaction over our 10 assessments, we saw substantial between-person variability in such change. That is, some couples experienced steeper declines in marital satisfaction than others. This variability puts us in the position of being able to use all baseline and time-varying variables to predict which couples are able to remain the most satisfied. All in all, we collected data on over 100 variables from this sample, and all variables are possible predictors of relationship outcomes. We will continue to develop complex predictions based on important theoretical perspectives that we test with very focused and well-thought out analyses. As a testament to the theoretical nature of our work, we have published nine articles so far using data from this data set that have appeared in some of the top journals in the field.
